spanishExample: ¡Buen día! ¿Cómo les va?
englishTranslation: Good morning! How is it going (for you all)?
vocabIncluded: cómo les va: how's it going? (plural) (idiom)

spanishExample: ¡Buenos días! Voy ahí esta tarde, así que hágalo.
englishTranslation: Good morning! I’ll go there this afternoon, so do it (formal).
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: ¡Qué bueno que todos puedan ir!
englishTranslation: How good that everyone is able to go!
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
puedan: "be able", "they be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)
qué: "what!" or "how!" in exclamations, as in "how lucky!"

spanishExample: Yo mismo la hice.
englishTranslation: I made it(f) myself(m).
vocabIncluded: mismo: adjective meaning "herself", "myself", etc. for emphasis (e.g. "yo misma")

spanishExample: ¿Cómo le va? ¿Cómo estuvo su noche?
englishTranslation: (formal) How is it going? How was your night?
vocabIncluded: cómo le va: how's it going? (formal) (idiom)
cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¿Cómo le va? Hoy vamos a hacerle ese favor.
englishTranslation: (formal) How is it going? Today we’re going to do you that favor.
vocabIncluded: cómo le va: how's it going? (formal) (idiom)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¿Cómo les va esta mañana? ¿Cómo han estado?
englishTranslation: How is it going (for you all) this morning? How have you been?
vocabIncluded: cómo les va: how's it going? (plural) (idiom)
cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: ¿Cómo te va? Mis cosas estaban aquí. ¿Las tienes?
englishTranslation: (informal) How is it going? My things were here. Do you have them?
vocabIncluded: cómo te va: how's it going? (idiom)
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things

spanishExample: ¿Cómo te va? Porque yo no estoy bien para nada.
englishTranslation: How is it going? Because I’m not well at all.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
cómo te va: how's it going? (idiom)

spanishExample: ¿Cuál *do you want?* Por favor *choose* uno.
englishTranslation: Which one do you want? Please choose one.

spanishExample: ¿Podremos ir a la casa y hacerlo de una vez por todas?
englishTranslation: Will we be able to go to the house and do it once and for all?
vocabIncluded: de una vez por todas: "once and for all" (idiom)

spanishExample: ¿Podrían hacerlo para que podamos estar con ella por un mes?
englishTranslation: Would they be able to do it so that we can be with her for a month?
vocabIncluded: podamos: "be able", "we be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 1st person plural)
podrían: "would be able", "they would be able" (Poder, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: ¿Podrías hacer eso? Yo lo haré cuando pueda.
englishTranslation: Would you be able to do that? I will do it when I can.
vocabIncluded: haré: "will do/make", "I will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person)
podrías: "would be able", "you would be able" (Poder, conditional, 2nd person)
pueda: "be able", "I be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Quién va a hacer el trabajo y dónde tenemos que ir?
englishTranslation: Who’s going to do the job and where do we have to go?
vocabIncluded: dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¿Todo bien? *I know* que el señor lo hizo mal.
englishTranslation: All good? I know the mister did it badly.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: A veces el hombre tenía tiempo.
englishTranslation: Sometimes the man had time.

spanishExample: El chico está solo porque no *he speaks* con nadie.
englishTranslation: The boy is lonely because he doesn’t speak with anyone.

spanishExample: El lugar es seguro y somos buenos. ¿Tú lo eres?
englishTranslation: The place is safe and we are good. Are you?
vocabIncluded: lo: "that way", "like that", constructed like a direct object (esp with Ser and Estar)
seguro: adjective meaning "safe" or "secure" when used with Ser

spanishExample: En ese entonces, no podían hacerlo.
englishTranslation: Back then, they weren't able to do it.
vocabIncluded: podían: "were able", "they were able" (Poder, imperfect, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: En ese lugar podíamos hacer un acuerdo.
englishTranslation: In that place we used to be able to make an agreement.
vocabIncluded: podíamos: "were able", "we were able" (Poder, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Está bien porque él no es bueno contigo.
englishTranslation: It’s fine because he’s not nice with you.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things

spanishExample: Está claro que es un buen hombre y lo haremos por él.
englishTranslation: It’s clear that he is a good man and we’ll do it for him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
claro: adjective meaning "clear" when used with Estar
haremos: "will do/make", "we will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Estamos seguros de que el chico tendrá dónde estar.
englishTranslation: We’re sure that the boy will have a place to be.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar
tendrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" (Tener, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Esto es un problema. *We want* que seas un mejor amigo.
englishTranslation: This is a problem. We want you to be a better friend.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Estoy seguro de que lo harán este mes.
englishTranslation: I’m sure they will do it this month.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar

spanishExample: Fueron al lugar para que nos hiciera ese favor.
englishTranslation: They went to the place so that he would do us that favor.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Fuimos buenos por un momento al estar ahí.
englishTranslation: We were nice for a moment upon being there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: Fuimos del lugar a la casa y por eso pude tenerlo.
englishTranslation: We went from the place to the house and that’s why I managed to have it.
vocabIncluded: del: "of the" before a masculine noun
pude: "was able / managed", "I was able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Gracias, pero ahora no pueden tenerlo.
englishTranslation: Thank you, but now they can’t have it.

spanishExample: Haber ido a la fiesta fue algo muy importante.
englishTranslation: Having gone to the party was something very important.
vocabIncluded: haber: "to have", "having" before a participle (Haber, infinitive)

spanishExample: Habíamos tenido dónde estar por un mes.
englishTranslation: We had had a place to be for a month.
vocabIncluded: habíamos: "had", "we had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Han hecho lo mismo y ahora mi amigo *wants* irse.
englishTranslation: They have done the same and now my friend(m) wants to leave.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Hicimos mucho en tres minutos.
englishTranslation: We did a lot in 3 minutes.

spanishExample: *I hope* que ni él ni yo tengamos tiempo para hacerlo.
englishTranslation: I hope that neither he nor I have time to do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: *I hope* que puedas ir a ese lugar y hacer todo eso a la vez.
englishTranslation: I hope you can go to that place and do all that at once.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
puedas: "be able", "you be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: *I hope* que tengan tiempo ahora.
englishTranslation: I hope they have time now.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I want* que puedan hacerlo, pero ellos *want* que yo lo haga.
englishTranslation: I want them to be able to do it, but they want me to do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
puedan: "be able", "they be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: La señora no ha podido ir, pero podría si tuviera tiempo.
englishTranslation: The Mrs. hasn’t been able to go, but she would be able to if she had time.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
podría: "would be able", "he/she/it would be able" (Poder, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: La señorita es tan buena que yo no me podría *compare* con ella.
englishTranslation: The young lady is so good that I wouldn’t be able to compare myself with her.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
podría: "would be able", "I would be able" (Poder, conditional, 1st person)
tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb

spanishExample: La verdad es que ella es la que te podría *help.*
englishTranslation: The truth is that she is the one that would be able to help you.
vocabIncluded: podría: "would be able", "he/she/it would be able" (Poder, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Lo había hecho *before,* pero ahora no iría ahí.
englishTranslation: I had done it before, but now I wouldn’t go there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
había: "had", "I had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person)
iría: "would go", "I would go" (Ir, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Lo hicimos por él.
englishTranslation: We did it on his behalf.

spanishExample: Los chicos están ahí ya que él pudo hacer eso.
englishTranslation: The boys are there since he managed to do that.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
pudo: "was able / managed", "he/she/it was able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 3rd person)
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: Mi amigo había hecho eso cuando eras *a kid.*
englishTranslation: My friend had done that when you were a kid.
vocabIncluded: había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Mis amigos hicieron todo lo que tenemos aquí.
englishTranslation: My friends made everything we have here.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: No puede ir ya mismo, pero lo hará cuando pueda.
englishTranslation: He can’t go this instant, but he’ll do it when he is able to.
vocabIncluded: hará: "will do/make", "he/she/it will do/make" (Hacer, future, 3rd person)
pueda: "be able", "he/she/it be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Pero se la *I gave* a usted.
englishTranslation: But I gave it (f) to you (formal).
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
usted: formal "you" after a preposition (prep. pronoun)

spanishExample: Podemos hacer eso ahora, pero en ese entonces no podíamos.
englishTranslation: We can do that now, but back then we weren’t able to.
vocabIncluded: podíamos: "were able", "we were able" (Poder, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Poder hacer eso era *important,* pero él no podía.
englishTranslation: Being able to do that was important, but he wasn’t able to.
vocabIncluded: podía: "was able", "he/she/it was able" (Poder, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Podía hacerlo, pero *I wanted* que otro hombre hiciera mi trabajo.
englishTranslation: I was able to do it, but I wanted another man to do my job.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
podía: "was able", "I was able" (Poder, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Podré hacerlo cuando esté ahí, así que está bien.
englishTranslation: I will be able to do it when I’m there, so it’s fine.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
podré: "will be able", "I will be able" (Poder, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Podríamos ir a esos lugares o hacer eso si lo* you prefer.*
englishTranslation: We would be able to go to those places or do that if you prefer it.
vocabIncluded: podríamos: "would be able", "we would be able" (Poder, conditional, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Por eso será el momento de ir ahí con alguien otra vez.
englishTranslation: That’s why it will be the moment to go there with someone again.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
será: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Ser, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Puede hacernos esos favores, pero iría al lugar esta tarde.
englishTranslation: He can do us those favors, but he would go to the place this afternoon.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
iría: "would go", "he/she/it would go" (Ir, conditional, 3rd person)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Puede que te vayas.
englishTranslation: It might be that you leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Puedo hacerlo al mismo tiempo que el chico.
englishTranslation: I can do it at the same time as the boy.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al mismo tiempo: "at the same time" (idiom)

spanishExample: Queremos que sean buenos porque hay chicos de más.
englishTranslation: We want them to be nice because there are extra guys.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: *I want* irme, pero en el pasado no me *happened* eso nunca.
englishTranslation: I want to leave, but in the past that didn’t ever happen to me.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Si estuviera en ese lugar, lo haría.
englishTranslation: If I were in that place, I would do it.
vocabIncluded: haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si fuera bueno, lo haría de vez en cuando.
englishTranslation: If he were nice, he would do it once in a while.
vocabIncluded: de vez en cuando: "once in a while" (idiom)
haría: "would do/make", "he/she/it would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si lo hiciera, nosotros no podríamos ir con él.
englishTranslation: If he did it, we wouldn’t be able to go with him.
vocabIncluded: podríamos: "would be able", "we would be able" (Poder, conditional, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Si pudiera hacerlo, lo haría para mañana.
englishTranslation: If I could do it, I would do it by tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: "para": "by" a moment in time, as in "by then"
haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)
pudiera: "were able", "I were able" (Poder, subjunctive past, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si pudiera hacerlo, lo haría porque él no puede.
englishTranslation: If I were able to do it, I would because he can’t.
vocabIncluded: haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)
pudiera: "were able", "I were able" (Poder, subjunctive past, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si tuviera tiempo, lo haría en una semana o un mes.
englishTranslation: If he had time, he would do it in a week or a month.
vocabIncluded: "o": "or" when used between items in a list
haría: "would do/make", "he/she/it would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si yo fuera él, sería tiempo de hacer eso.
englishTranslation: If I were him, it would be time to do that.
vocabIncluded: sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Siempre le hago ese favor y estoy feliz.
englishTranslation: I always do her that favor and I’m happy.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Te *I told* que no podías ser así cuando estabas ahí.
englishTranslation: I told you you weren’t able to be like that when you were there.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
podías: "were able", "you were able" (Poder, imperfect, 2nd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Tendré mis cosas ahí solo si tú vas.
englishTranslation: I will have my things there only if you go.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
tendré: "will have", "I will have" (Tener, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Tendríamos que hacerlo a esa hora con cuidado.
englishTranslation: We would have to do it at that time carefully.
vocabIncluded: tendríamos: "would have", "we would have" (Tener, conditional, 1st person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tenía muchos problemas, más que esos.
englishTranslation: I had a lot of problems, more than those.

spanishExample: Tiempo al tiempo, esa chica no es tu amiga ahora.
englishTranslation: Give it time, that girl is not your friend right now.

spanishExample: Tienes que tener cuidado porque no será seguro.
englishTranslation: You have to be careful because it will not be safe.
vocabIncluded: seguro: adjective meaning "safe" or "secure" when used with Ser
será: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Ser, future, 3rd person)
tener cuidado: "to be careful" (idiom, lit. "to have carefulness")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tú hacías lo que podías cuando eras *young.*
englishTranslation: You used to do what you were able to when you were young.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
hacías: "were doing/making", "you were doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 2nd person)
podías: "were able", "you were able" (Poder, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Una vez que lo tuvo, se fue.
englishTranslation: Once she had it, she left.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
una vez que: idiom meaning "once", right before another phrase

spanishExample: Vamos a hacer una fiesta.
englishTranslation: We’re going to throw a party.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Van a ese lugar y nos vamos con ellos.
englishTranslation: They go to that place and we leave with them.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Vas a hacer esas cosas para que yo sea bueno contigo.
englishTranslation: You are going to do those things in order for me to be nice with you.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
